ai-mn129:47.3_0: Which is bigger: the stone the size of my palm that I’ve picked up, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”
ai-mn129:47.4_0: “Sir, the stone you’ve picked up is tiny.
ai-mn129:47.4_1: Compared to the Himalayas, the king of mountains, is not worth a fraction,
ai-mn129:47.4_3: nor does the world make me harm.”
ai-mn129:47.5_0: “In the same way, compared to the happiness of heaven, the pleasure and happiness experienced by a wheel-turning monarch due to those seven treasures and those four blessings doesn’t even count, it’s not even a fraction, there’s no comparison.
ai-mn129:48.1_0: And suppose that astute person, after a very long time, returned to the human realm.
ai-mn129:48.2_0: They’d be reborn in a well-to-do family of aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain.
ai-mn129:48.3_0: And they’d be attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. They’d get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; and a bed, house, and lighting.
ai-mn129:48.4_0: conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.
ai-mn129:48.5_0: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-mn129:49.1_0: Suppose a gambler on the first lucky throw was to win a big pile of money.
ai-mn129:49.2_0: But such an unlucky throw was trivial compared to the first lucky throw.
ai-mn129:49.3_0: the lucky throw whereby an astute person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
ai-mn129:49.4_0: This is the total fulfillment of the astute person’s level.”
ai-mn129:49.5_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn129:49.6_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn129:49.7_0: The ninth section on the ignorant and incompetent is finished.
